newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bundesbank data shows German economy a bit stronger.
newsitem.headline: Bundesbank data shows German economy a bit stronger.

text.p: Bundesbank data released on Wednesday showed that the German economy was slightly stronger in the fourth quarter than previously believed.

But economists said the picture was still not one of a vigorous recovery -- which would help allay some fears over meeting criteria for a single European currency -- and the outlook for the current quarter remained slack as consumer demand was still subdued.

The central bank statistics showed a rise of 0.1 percent in gross domestic product (GDP) in the fourth quarter of 1996 from the previous quarter and of 2.2 percent from a year earlier. The growth rates were calculated by Reuters from the raw data.
Earlier Bundesbank figures two weeks ago had shown a 0.2 percent decline from the previous quarter and 1.6 percent year-on-year rise.
"These data show the economy was not as weak as we thought. At least now it's not a fall but a marginal rise," said economist Holger Fahrinkrug at UBS in Frankfurt.
"Still, even these numbers are highly uncertain. Seasonal adjustments are putting a bias on the data. The 2.2 percent in particular looks excessively strong," Fahrinkrug said.

Federal Statistics Office data on Wednesday put the fourth-quarter year-on-year rise at only 1.9 percent. The main strength of the new Bundesbank data results from downward revisions to earlier figures.

Economics Minister Guenter Rexrodt said the flat fourth quarter was not a sign of a renewed period of economic weakness and the government stood by its forecast of 2.5 percent economic growth this year. Most private-sector economists predict lower growth of about 2.0 percent.
Slow growth and rising unemployment are boosting government outlays while cutting tax revenues.

The squeeze fuels fear that Germany might not meet the guidelines to qualify for the planned European single currency, a prospect that could scupper the entire project, scheduled to start in January 1999.

Some economists say the European Union's Maastricht Treaty gives leeway on the guidelines for economic and monetary union (EMU) but German officials have been among the most dogmatic advocates of a strict interpretation.

"With these figures Germany won't meet the EMU criteria perfectly but that is enough for a start of EMU in 1999. With figures that close to the EMU criteria, EMU will go forward," said Christian Sobotta of LGT Asset Management in Frankfurt.
Sobotta sees Germany's budget deficit at 3.1 percent of GDP in 1997, the key year for deciding the initial EMU members.

Many economists believe the economy remains sluggish in the current quarter, as witnessed by labour market weakness and a decline in industrial production in January. Industrial output fell 1.7 percent from December, mainly due to a sharp fall in construction output, the Economics Ministry reported.
But they say the strong dollar should help fuel German exports and reinforce growth starting in the second quarter.
"We may see a flat first quarter. But thereafter we see similar strength as we saw last year, particularly in exports brought on by the weaker mark," said David Brickman of Yamaichi International.
"But German consumption is particularly weak. That is something that is going to continue and offset the weaker mark," Brickman said.

Despite the overall sluggishness, economists see almost no chance of the Bundesbank cutting interest rates soon. Price rises have accelerated in recent months and the weakness of the mark is a potential inflationary factor.

"The arguments in favour and against an interest rate decrease balance each other out. For the time being the Bundesbank is likely to continue its steady hand policy," said Hermann Remsperger of BHF-Bank.

The central bank holds its next policy-making council meeting on Thursday. Also due then are unemployment figures for February which economists expect to show another postwar record of 4.32 million on a seasonally adjusted basis, up about 20,000 from January.
